dt: {bc}the finding or decision of a jury on the matter submitted to it in trial

et: Middle English {it}verdit, verdict{/it}, borrowed from Anglo-French {it}veirdit{/it} "announcement, finding, judicial decision," from {it}veir{/it} "true" (going back to Latin {it}vērus{/it}) + {it}dit{/it} "statement, judgment" (going back to Latin {it}dictum{/it}), after Medieval Latin {it}vērumdictum, vēredictum{/it} {ma}{mat|very:2|}, {mat|dictum|}{/ma}
shortdef: the finding or decision of a jury on the matter submitted to it in trial

dt: {bc}a verdict of not proven that is allowed by Scottish criminal law in some cases instead of a verdict of not guilty

shortdef: a verdict of not proven that is allowed by Scottish criminal law in some cases instead of a verdict of not guilty

dt: {bc}an official statement or decision saying that a crime has been committed but not naming a criminal, or saying that there has been a death but not naming the cause of death

shortdef: an official statement or decision saying that a crime has been committed but not naming a criminal, or saying that there has been a death but not naming the cause of death
